name: Montreal
fun_fact: Fun fact: Montreal-style bagels are boiled in honey-sweetened water and baked in wood-fired ovens, making them sweeter, denser, and smaller than New York bagels - a technique brought by Jewish immigrants in 1919 that hasn't changed in over a century.

hero_dishes.name: Poutine
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fries topped with squeaky cheese curds and rich brown gravy. The authentic version requires fresh curds that squeak when bitten.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in rural Quebec in the 1950s, poutine was considered low-class until Montreal elevated it to art form. Now it's Quebec's most famous export, with endless variations from foie gras to lobster.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chez Tousignant (all-beef poutine with housemade potato buns), La Banquise (24/7 with 30+ varieties)

hero_dishes.name: Montreal Smoked Meat Sandwich
hero_dishes.description: Thick-cut, hand-sliced smoked brisket on rye bread with mustard. The meat is cured for 10 days, smoked, and steamed until fork-tender.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by Jewish immigrants from Romania in the 1920s, Montreal smoked meat is distinct from pastrami with its unique spice blend and smoking technique. It's a cultural institution that defines the city.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Schwartz's Deli (the 1928 original, always a line), Main Deli Steak House

hero_dishes.description: Traditional meat pie made with pork, beef, or veal, spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and allspice, baked in flaky pastry.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Quebecois Christmas tradition dating back to the 1600s, tourtiÃ¨re was originally made with wild game and passenger pigeons. Each family guards their own secret spice blend.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Binerie (serving since 1938), La Part des Anges (contemporary version)

hero_dishes.name: Authentic Thai Noodles at Bangluck
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Thai street noodles like kuay tiew heng (rice noodles with soy sauce, pork, and fried fish balls) and kuay tiew tomyum (spicy-sour soup).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Opened in 2024 by Thai couple Chita and Nim, Bangluck deliberately avoids tourist dishes like pad Thai, instead serving the authentic noodle shop experience found on Bangkok's streets.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bangluck (one of Montreal's best new restaurants of 2024)

signature_drinks.name: Caribou
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Quebec winter drink made with red wine, whisky (or brandy), maple syrup, and spices.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed hot during winter festivals, especially Carnaval de QuÃ©bec. Often served from a boot-shaped flask. It's dangerously smooth and deceptively strong.

signature_drinks.name: SortilÃ¨ge (Maple Whisky)
signature_drinks.description: Canadian whisky blended with pure Quebec maple syrup, creating a smooth, sweet spirit.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped neat or on ice, particularly after dinner. Also popular in cocktails at Montreal's natural wine bars like Mon Lapin.

food_culture_notes: Montreal has a unique food culture split between French bistro traditions and Jewish deli heritage
The city's bagel wars (St-Viateur vs Fairmount) have divided locals since the 1950s - both use wood-fired ovens operating 24/7
Natural wine bars and farm-to-table restaurants dominate the Mile End and Plateau neighborhoods
Quebec laws require menus to be in French first, but Montreal's food scene is decidedly international
